column2: Potential Indirect (Enablers or Proxies) Corelating Data Points

column4: How It Shows Up in the Market

column3: Digital payment rails vs. merchant acceptance
column4: Unlike global norms where P2P is mostly for transfers, in Ethiopia actual payments (e.g., goods/services) often occur on P2P rails
column5: When benchmarking Ethiopia on “digital payments,” global frameworks may understate real usage; baselines should differentiate P2P for transfers vs. P2P for commerce etc.

column2: Mobile Money-Only Users Are Extremely Rare
column4: In Ethiopia, only ~0.5% of adults have mobile money without a bank account, unlike many SSA markets where mobile money is the primary inclusion driver
column5: Global assumptions that mobile money is the main on-ramp don’t hold in Ethiopia; baselines should segment “bank-only” vs “mobile money-only” vs “both”

column3: Comparision of the requirements to open a financial account in Ethiopia with other countries

column2: Very Low Formal Credit Penetration (Even by African Standards)
column5: Customer onboarding without credit is easy; building credit products is hard.
